div.h2: Parkview Distance Learning Begins Monday, March 23rd

div.p:
"Parkview distance learning begins Monday March 23rd. Click here to access the PES Distance Learning site and here to access the PJH/PHS Distance Learning site."

span.a: You are currently on this page - COVID 19 - Resources

td.h3: Schools Closed through April 3 - CLICK HERE for a message from Superintendent Lutzke
td.p:
Today at 4:30 Governor Evers ordered all K-12 WI schools closed in relation to the COVID-19 situation. I would like to share information with you related to this announcement. First, we are all aware of the level of national concern related to COVID-19. For the sake of our students, I urge everyone to only share factual information and try not to speculate. Our students need to see all adults providing a safe and caring environment in a time of uncertainty. We are all in this together.
Parkview has decided to close beginning Monday, March 16, 2020 and will remain closed pending guidance from our local, state, and federal health officials. Current guidance states the earliest return date would be April 6, 2020. April 6 is supposed to be the start of spring break and it is highly likely that spring break will be moved to the week of March 30-April 3. Beginning Monday, March 16 all school activities and events on our campuses (including spring sports) are suspended until further notice.
Parkview staff will be working next week to develop a contingency plan in an attempt for instruction to continue. You can anticipate more communication of these plans later next week.
Parkview strongly recommends that all families comply with the Center for Disease Control guidance and avoid non-essential travel outside of our immediate geographic region. Most major airlines have initiated policies that allow for free changes or temporary suspension of flights. The Wisconsin State Department of Health Services recommends that people who travel to places where there is community spread of COVID-19 (which is basically the entire US and abroad) self-quarantine and monitor for symptoms for 14 days upon return.
We are sensitive to other needs that families may have and we will do our best to support our community during this challenging time
td.h4: School Meals - CLICK HERE for more information
td.p: Monday, children will receive two grab and go breakfast meals intended for Tuesday and Wednesday mornings. They will also receive 2 Grab and Go lunch meals intended for Monday and Tuesday.
Wednesday, children will receive two grab and go breakfast meals intended for Thursday and Friday mornings. They will also receive 2 Grab and Go lunch meals intended for Wednesday and Thursday.
Friday, children will receive one grab and go breakfast meal intended for Monday morning and one grab and go lunch meal intended for Friday.
Click here to access the PES Distance Learning site and here to access the PJH/PHS Distance Learning site."
Some internet carriers are offering free and/or low cost options that your family may be able to use.
See DPI list of internet offers for families

Spectrum is offering free broadband internet and WiFi access for 60 days to families with K-12 and college students. Charter, which operates Spectrum internet, said they will also waive installation fees for new households. Learn more about the Spectrum offer here or call 844-488-8395.
Comcast Internet Essentials indicated that they are providing 60 days of free internet to qualifying families. Learn more about the Comcast offer.
For students with Special Education needs, please contact our Special Education/Pupil Services Director Todd Greco (608) 879-2994 ext. 5114

img.alt: Symptoms of Coronavirus - fever, cough and shortness of breath

td.div: The safety of our students and staff is our top priority. When school resumes, please watch for the following symptoms. Keep students home from school and contact their physician to ask to be tested for Coronavirus if they have these symptoms:
td.p: Please contact the school 608-879-2994 (Jr. Sr) or 608-879-2956 (PES) to report the absence and symptoms. Learn more about the symptoms and treatment of Coronavirus at the Center for Disease Control (CDC) website. Those at highest risk for Coronavirus complications are older adults and individuals with compromised immune systems or heart, lung and kidney disease. See how Coronavirus is spread. It can take two to 14 days for a person to develop symptoms after initial exposure to the virus; the average is about five days.

p.strong: We have no known cases of COVID-19 among students or staff in Parkview School District.

td.p: We continue to closely monitor the situation with our School Nurses and Rock County Health Departments, as well as review updates from the Wisconsin Department of Health Services, Department of Public Instruction and the CDC. Here is the latest information on confirmed cases in Wisconsin - in Brown, Dane, Fond Du Lac, Kenosha, La Crosse, Milwaukee, Outagamie, Pierce, Racine, Sheboygan, Washington, Waukesha, Winnebago and Wood counties. Another approximately 30 WI residents returned March 16 from a cruise where they may have been exposed and will be self-quarantined for 14 days.

li.a: GOV EVERS: WI School Closure Information - 3/17/20
li.br: State bans gatherings of 10 or more. DPI This does not prevent school staff from coming to the building, as long as more than 9 individuals are not gathered in one space, says Mike Thompson, PhD, WI Deputy State Superintendent.
